clinical_study.official_title: Evaluation of Blood Biospectroscopy as a Novel Diagnostic Test for Idiopathic Parkinson Disease

collaborator.agency: Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research

brief_summary.textblock: The primary objective of the study is to determine the utility of blood plasma infrared spectroscopy (biospectroscopy) in distinguishing subjects with idiopathic Parkinson's disease from healthy controls.

detailed_description.textblock: Oxidative stress has been implicated as a factor in the pathogenesis of Parkinson's disease (PD). The overall goal of this proposal is to use a novel metabolomics platform, based on near infrared biospectroscopy, to detect oxidatively modified blood plasma constituents. These spectral findings can be used to model the degree of oxidative stress with a modeled "stress index" that may distinguish PD cases from healthy elderly controls.

primary_outcome.measure: The primary outcome of the study is the correct classification of cases of PD and controls. This will be quantified as sensitivity and specificity.
primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline and annually for two years

secondary_outcome.measure: Determine impact of disease stage, age, gender, medications, cognitive scores, other laboratory measures (e.g. alpha-synuclein) and other clinical/demographic variables on plasma biospectra.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline and annually for two years

secondary_outcome.measure: Correlate plasma biospectra with dopamine transporter neuroimaging data.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline and annually for two years

arm_group.description: Subjects with current Parkinson Disease Diagnosis currently enrolled in PostCEPT study
Non-blood relatives of PostCEPT Subjects matched for age and other demographics

intervention.description: Blood draw, two tubes, used for isolation of cell-free blood plasma

study_pop.textblock: Parkinson's subjects: from pool of subjects currently enrolled in PostCEPT study Control subjects: general population

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
PD Subjects:
1. PostCEPT subjects with a diagnosis of PD based on UK Brain Bank criteria.
2. Willing and able to provide informed consent.
Healthy Controls:
1. No current diagnosis or known history of a neurological disease/disorder.
2. Non-blood relative of a patient or subject at the site who has diagnosis of PD (may include healthy controls from the PROBE study).
3. No first degree relatives with diagnosis of PD
4. MoCA score > 26.
5. Age > 45.
6. Willing and able to provide informed consent.

link.description: The Parkinson Study Group (PSG) is a non-profit, cooperative group of Parkinson's disease experts from medical centers in the United States and Canada who are dedicated to improving treatment for persons affected by Parkinson's disease.
